splunk.content: Splunk is a leading data platform for security and observability, providing real-time visibility into machine-generated data from virtually any source.

sections.heading: Key Capabilities
list: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) - Centralized log collection, correlation, and security monitoring
Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) - Automated incident response workflows
User and Entity Behavior Analytics (UEBA) - Machine learning-driven threat detection
Threat Intelligence Platform - Integration with threat feeds and IOC management

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Log aggregation and centralized monitoring
Real-time security alerting and incident detection
Compliance reporting and audit trails
Forensic investigation and threat hunting
Application performance monitoring

sections.heading: Related Technologies
sections.content: Splunk integrates with a wide ecosystem of security tools and data sources, making it a cornerstone of modern Security Operations Centers (SOCs).

alienvault.content: AlienVault, now AT&T Cybersecurity USM (Unified Security Management), provides an all-in-one security platform combining multiple essential security capabilities.

sections.heading: Key Capabilities
list: Asset Discovery - Automatic identification and inventory of network assets
Vulnerability Assessment - Continuous scanning for security weaknesses
Intrusion Detection - Network and host-based threat detection
Behavioral Monitoring - Detection of anomalous activities
SIEM & Log Management - Centralized logging and event correlation

sections.heading: Open Threat Exchange (OTX)
sections.content: AlienVault operates the Open Threat Exchange, one of the world's largest open threat intelligence communities, enabling collaborative defense through shared indicators of compromise.

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Small to mid-sized enterprise security monitoring
Managed Security Service Providers (MSSPs)
Compliance monitoring (PCI DSS, HIPAA, SOC 2)
Threat detection and response

elastic.content: The Elastic Stack (formerly ELK Stack) is a powerful open-source platform for search, observability, and security built on Elasticsearch, Kibana, Beats, and Logstash.

sections.heading: Core Components
list: Elasticsearch - Distributed search and analytics engine
Kibana - Data visualization and exploration interface
Logstash - Server-side data processing pipeline
Beats - Lightweight data shippers for various data types

sections.heading: Security Capabilities
list: Elastic Security - SIEM functionality with detection rules and case management
Endpoint Security - Host-based protection and EDR capabilities
Threat Hunting - Interactive investigation and hunting workflows
Machine Learning - Anomaly detection and behavioral analysis

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Log aggregation and analysis at scale
Security monitoring and threat detection
Application performance monitoring (APM)
Infrastructure monitoring
Full-text search applications

qradar.content: IBM QRadar is an enterprise-grade security intelligence platform that provides real-time visibility and advanced threat detection across the entire IT infrastructure.

sections.heading: Key Capabilities
list: Log Management - Centralized collection and normalization of security events
Network Flow Analysis - Deep packet inspection and flow-based analytics
Offense Management - Automated correlation and prioritization of security incidents
Threat Intelligence - Integration with IBM X-Force and third-party feeds
Risk Assessment - Asset-based risk scoring and vulnerability correlation

sections.heading: Advanced Features
list: QRadar Advisor with Watson - AI-powered investigation assistance
User Behavior Analytics - Detection of insider threats and compromised credentials
Network Insights - Enhanced network visibility and application identification

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Large enterprise security operations
Advanced persistent threat (APT) detection
Regulatory compliance (SOX, PCI DSS, HIPAA)
Incident investigation and forensics

opensearch.content: OpenSearch is a community-driven, open-source search and analytics suite derived from Elasticsearch and Kibana, maintained by AWS and a growing community of contributors.

sections.heading: Core Components
list: OpenSearch - Distributed search and analytics engine
OpenSearch Dashboards - Visualization and user interface
Data Prepper - Server-side data collector for trace and log data

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Full-Text Search - Powerful search capabilities with relevance scoring
Log Analytics - Centralized logging and analysis at scale
Trace Analytics - Distributed tracing for microservices
Security Analytics - SIEM capabilities with detection rules
Anomaly Detection - Machine learning-based anomaly detection

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Cost-effective alternative to commercial SIEM solutions
Log aggregation and observability
Security monitoring and compliance
Application search functionality
Business intelligence and analytics

kubernetes.content: Kubernetes (K8s) is an open-source container orchestration platform that automates the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

sections.heading: Core Concepts
list: Pods - Smallest deployable units containing containers
Services - Network abstraction for pod communication
Deployments - Declarative updates for Pods and ReplicaSets
Namespaces - Virtual clusters for resource isolation
ConfigMaps and Secrets - Configuration and sensitive data management

sections.heading: Security Features
list: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) - Fine-grained permissions
Network Policies - Pod-level network segmentation
Pod Security Standards - Security context constraints
Secrets Management - Encrypted storage for sensitive data
Admission Controllers - Policy enforcement at creation time

sections.heading: Security Best Practices
list: Implement least privilege for service accounts
Use network policies for micro-segmentation
Scan container images for vulnerabilities
Enable audit logging
Keep clusters and components updated

docker.content: Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers, providing lightweight isolation and consistent environments across development and production.

sections.heading: Core Components
list: Docker Engine - Runtime for building and running containers
Docker Images - Read-only templates for containers
Docker Containers - Running instances of images
Docker Compose - Multi-container application definition
Docker Registry - Storage and distribution of images

sections.heading: Security Considerations
list: Image Security - Use trusted base images and scan for vulnerabilities
Container Isolation - Namespace and cgroup isolation
Least Privilege - Run as non-root users
Secrets Management - Avoid hardcoded credentials
Network Security - Use custom networks and limit exposure

sections.heading: Best Practices
list: Use minimal base images (Alpine, distroless)
Multi-stage builds for smaller images
Sign and verify images
Implement resource limits
Regular vulnerability scanning

ansible.content: Ansible is an open-source automation platform that provides simple, powerful automation for configuration management, application deployment, and orchestration.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Agentless Architecture - No software required on managed nodes
YAML-Based Playbooks - Human-readable automation definitions
Idempotent Operations - Safe to run multiple times
Extensive Module Library - Support for virtually any system
Ansible Galaxy - Community-contributed roles and collections

sections.heading: Security Automation Use Cases
list: Security baseline configuration
Compliance enforcement and remediation
Patch management automation
Certificate and secret rotation
Firewall and network configuration
User access management

sections.heading: Integration
sections.content: Ansible integrates with container platforms like Kubernetes and Docker, cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP), and security tools to enable comprehensive infrastructure as code (IaC) workflows.

go.content: Go (Golang) is a statically typed, compiled programming language designed at Google for simplicity, efficiency, and reliable software development.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Simplicity - Clean syntax with minimal keywords
Concurrency - Built-in goroutines and channels for parallel processing
Fast Compilation - Quick build times for rapid development
Static Binaries - Single executable with no external dependencies
Strong Typing - Compile-time error detection
Garbage Collection - Automatic memory management

sections.heading: Security Applications
list: Command-line security tools
Network scanning and analysis tools
Container and cloud-native security applications
API development and microservices
Cryptographic implementations

sections.heading: Notable Security Tools in Go
sections.content: Many popular security tools are written in Go, including Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform, and numerous offensive and defensive security tools due to its cross-platform compilation and performance characteristics.

python.content: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and extensive library ecosystem, making it ideal for security automation and analysis.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Readable Syntax - Clear, expressive code structure
Extensive Libraries - Rich ecosystem for security, data analysis, and automation
Cross-Platform - Runs on Windows, Linux, and macOS
Rapid Prototyping - Quick development for scripts and tools
Community Support - Large, active security community

sections.heading: Security Applications
list: Automation - Security task scripting and workflow automation
Penetration Testing - Exploit development and vulnerability research
Malware Analysis - Binary analysis and reverse engineering
Data Analysis - Log analysis and threat intelligence processing
API Integration - Security tool orchestration

sections.heading: Popular Security Libraries
list: requests - HTTP library for API interaction
scapy - Packet manipulation and network analysis
pycryptodome - Cryptographic operations
pandas - Data analysis and manipulation
yara-python - Malware pattern matching

git.content: Git is a distributed version control system designed for tracking changes in source code and enabling collaborative development workflows.

sections.heading: Key Concepts
list: Repositories - Project containers with complete history
Branches - Parallel development lines
Commits - Snapshots of project state
Merging - Combining changes from different branches
Remote Repositories - Shared repositories for collaboration

sections.heading: Security Considerations
list: Signed Commits - GPG signing for authenticity verification
Access Control - Repository permissions and branch protection
Secret Management - Keeping credentials out of repositories
Audit Trail - Complete history of all changes
Code Review - Pull request workflows for security review

sections.heading: DevSecOps Integration
sections.content: Git is foundational to DevSecOps practices, enabling infrastructure as code, configuration management versioning, security policy as code, and automated security testing in CI/CD pipelines.

vagrant.content: Vagrant is an open-source tool for building and managing virtualized development environments, enabling consistent, reproducible infrastructure across teams.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Declarative Configuration - Vagrantfiles define environment specifications
Provider Agnostic - Support for VirtualBox, VMware, Hyper-V, and more
Provisioning Integration - Works with Ansible, Chef, Puppet, and shell scripts
Box Ecosystem - Pre-built base images for quick starts
Networking - Configurable private and public networking

sections.heading: Security Use Cases
list: Lab Environments - Isolated security testing and research
Malware Analysis - Disposable analysis environments
Penetration Testing - Reproducible target environments
Training - Consistent lab setups for security training
Development - Secure, isolated development environments

sections.heading: Benefits
sections.content: Vagrant enables security professionals to quickly spin up and tear down complex multi-machine environments for testing, training, and research without affecting production systems.

connectwise.content: ConnectWise provides a comprehensive suite of IT service management and remote monitoring tools designed for Managed Service Providers (MSPs) and IT departments.

sections.heading: Key Products
list: ConnectWise Automate - Remote monitoring and management (RMM)
ConnectWise Manage - Professional Services Automation (PSA)
ConnectWise Control - Remote support and access
ConnectWise SIEM - Security information and event management

sections.heading: Security Capabilities
list: Endpoint Monitoring - Real-time system health and security monitoring
Patch Management - Automated patching for operating systems and applications
Antivirus Integration - Centralized AV deployment and management
Compliance Reporting - Documentation for regulatory requirements
Alerting - Customizable security and operational alerts

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: MSP service delivery and management
Enterprise IT operations
Security monitoring and response
Compliance management
Remote workforce support

kaseya.content: Kaseya provides IT infrastructure management solutions including remote monitoring, security, and compliance tools for MSPs and enterprise IT teams.

sections.heading: Key Products
list: Kaseya VSA - Remote monitoring and management platform
Datto RMM - Cloud-based remote monitoring (acquired by Kaseya)
Unitrends - Backup and disaster recovery
IT Glue - IT documentation platform

sections.heading: Security Features
list: Endpoint Detection and Response - Threat detection on managed devices
Patch Management - Automated security patching
Backup Monitoring - Data protection verification
Compliance Automation - Policy enforcement and reporting
Network Monitoring - Infrastructure security oversight

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: MSP operations and service delivery
IT asset management
Security baseline enforcement
Disaster recovery planning
Multi-tenant environment management

mitre-attack.content: MITRE ATT&CK (Adversarial Tactics, Techniques, and Common Knowledge) is a globally-accessible knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations.

sections.heading: Framework Structure
list: Tactics - The adversary's tactical goals (the "why")
Techniques - How adversaries achieve tactical goals (the "how")
Sub-techniques - More specific descriptions of adversarial behavior
Procedures - Specific implementations observed in the wild
Mitigations - Security controls to prevent or detect techniques
Groups - Known threat actor profiles

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Threat Intelligence - Mapping threats to known adversary behaviors
Detection Engineering - Building detections aligned to techniques
Red Team Operations - Emulating real-world adversary tradecraft
Gap Analysis - Identifying defensive coverage gaps
Communication - Common language for security discussions

sections.heading: Integration
sections.content: MITRE ATT&CK integrates with STIX/TAXII for machine-readable threat intelligence sharing and is widely adopted across security tools, frameworks, and organizations.

stix.content: STIX (Structured Threat Information eXpression) is a standardized language for representing and sharing cyber threat intelligence in a structured, machine-readable format.

sections.heading: Core Concepts
list: STIX Domain Objects (SDOs) - Attack patterns, campaigns, indicators, malware, threat actors, tools, vulnerabilities
STIX Relationship Objects (SROs) - Connections between objects
STIX Cyber Observable Objects (SCOs) - Technical observables like IPs, domains, files
STIX Bundle - Collection of STIX objects

sections.heading: Key Features
list: JSON-Based Format - Human and machine-readable
Extensibility - Custom objects and properties
Versioning - Track changes to threat intelligence
Relationships - Rich connections between data points

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Threat intelligence sharing between organizations
Automated ingestion of threat feeds
Incident documentation and analysis
Integration with SIEM and security tools
Regulatory and compliance reporting

taxii.content: TAXII (Trusted Automated eXchange of Intelligence Information) is a transport protocol designed for sharing cyber threat intelligence in a standardized, automated manner.

sections.heading: Core Concepts
list: Collections - Sets of STIX objects organized by topic or source
Channels - Publication mechanism for threat intelligence
API Roots - Logical groupings of collections and channels
Discovery - Finding available TAXII services

sections.heading: Service Models
list: Collection Service - Request-response retrieval of threat intelligence
Channel Service - Publish-subscribe distribution model

sections.heading: Key Features
list: RESTful API - Standard HTTP-based communication
Authentication - Secure access control
Pagination - Handling large datasets efficiently
Filtering - Query specific threat intelligence

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Automated threat feed consumption
Sharing indicators between organizations
ISAC/ISAO information sharing
Threat intelligence platform integration

veris.content: VERIS (Vocabulary for Event Recording and Incident Sharing) is a standardized framework for collecting and sharing information about security incidents in a structured, consistent manner.

sections.heading: Framework Structure
sections.content: The VERIS framework uses the A4 threat model:
list: Actors - Who is behind the incident (external, internal, partner)
Actions - What tactics were used (malware, hacking, social, etc.)
Assets - What assets were affected (servers, user devices, data)
Attributes - How assets were affected (confidentiality, integrity, availability)

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Standardized Vocabulary - Consistent incident categorization
Enumerations - Predefined values for common attributes
JSON Schema - Machine-readable format
Metrics Focus - Designed for statistical analysis

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Security incident documentation
Trend analysis and reporting
Benchmarking against industry data
Risk assessment and prioritization
Compliance and audit documentation

sections.heading: Related Projects
sections.content: VERIS is the foundation of the Verizon Data Breach Investigations Report (DBIR), providing the methodology for one of the industry's most comprehensive security research publications.

hyper-v.content: Hyper-V is Microsoft's hardware virtualization platform, providing enterprise-grade virtualization capabilities natively integrated with Windows Server and Windows 10/11 Pro.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Type 1 Hypervisor - Runs directly on hardware for better performance
Live Migration - Move running VMs between hosts without downtime
Replica - Asynchronous replication for disaster recovery
Generation 2 VMs - UEFI-based VMs with Secure Boot support
Shielded VMs - Protected VMs for sensitive workloads

sections.heading: Security Capabilities
list: Secure Boot - Prevent unauthorized OS and bootloader execution
Virtual TPM - Virtualized Trusted Platform Module
Host Guardian Service - Attestation for shielded VM hosts
Network Isolation - Software-defined networking and microsegmentation
Integration with Windows Security - Credential Guard, Device Guard

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Enterprise server virtualization
Development and testing environments
Security lab infrastructure
Disaster recovery solutions
Windows-centric virtualization deployments

esxi.content: VMware ESXi is a Type 1 bare-metal hypervisor that forms the foundation of VMware's virtualization platform, widely deployed in enterprise data centers globally.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Bare-Metal Architecture - Direct hardware access for maximum performance
vMotion - Live migration of running VMs
High Availability - Automatic VM restart on host failure
Distributed Resource Scheduler - Automatic load balancing
vSAN - Software-defined storage integration

sections.heading: Security Features
list: vSphere Trust Authority - Hardware and software attestation
VM Encryption - Encryption of VM files and vMotion traffic
Secure Boot - UEFI Secure Boot for VMs and hypervisor
Role-Based Access Control - Granular permissions management
Audit Logging - Comprehensive activity tracking

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Enterprise data center virtualization
Private cloud infrastructure
Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI)
Development and test environments
Disaster recovery and business continuity

kvm.content: KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is a full virtualization solution for Linux that turns the Linux kernel into a Type 1 hypervisor, leveraging hardware virtualization extensions.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Kernel Integration - Built into the Linux kernel since 2.6.20
Hardware Acceleration - Uses Intel VT-x and AMD-V extensions
QEMU Integration - Works with QEMU for device emulation
Live Migration - Move running VMs between hosts
Memory Management - Kernel Same-page Merging (KSM) for efficiency

sections.heading: Security Features
list: SELinux Integration - Mandatory access control for VMs
sVirt - Security framework for VM isolation
Secure Boot - UEFI Secure Boot support
Memory Encryption - AMD SEV and Intel TME support
Namespaces and Cgroups - Resource isolation

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Linux-based server virtualization
Cloud infrastructure (OpenStack, Proxmox)
Cost-effective enterprise virtualization
Security research and malware analysis labs
Development environments

xen.content: Xen is an open-source Type 1 hypervisor that runs directly on hardware, providing strong isolation between virtual machines and forming the foundation of many cloud platforms.

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Paravirtualization - Modified guest OS for improved performance
Hardware Virtual Machine (HVM) - Full virtualization support
PVH Mode - Combines PV and HVM benefits
Live Migration - Move running VMs without downtime
Dom0 - Privileged management domain

sections.heading: Security Architecture
list: Minimal TCB - Small trusted computing base
Disaggregation - Separation of privileged functions
XSM/FLASK - Mandatory access control
Stub Domains - Isolated device emulation
Memory Isolation - Hardware-enforced separation

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Cloud infrastructure (AWS EC2 originally used Xen)
High-security environments (Qubes OS)
Server consolidation
Multi-tenant hosting
Research and development

qemu.content: QEMU (Quick Emulator) is a versatile open-source machine emulator and virtualizer that can emulate various hardware platforms or work with KVM for near-native virtualization performance.

sections.heading: Operating Modes
list: Full System Emulation - Emulates complete hardware systems
User Mode Emulation - Run binaries for different architectures
KVM Acceleration - Near-native performance with hardware support
Xen Integration - Works as a device model for Xen

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Multi-Architecture - x86, ARM, MIPS, PowerPC, and more
Device Emulation - Extensive hardware device support
Snapshot Support - Save and restore VM states
Live Migration - Move running instances between hosts
Flexible Disk Formats - qcow2, raw, vmdk, and others

sections.heading: Security Use Cases
list: Malware Analysis - Isolated analysis environments
Reverse Engineering - Run binaries from different architectures
Fuzzing - Test software on various platforms
Security Research - Kernel and driver development
CTF Challenges - Cross-architecture challenge solving

smartos.content: SmartOS is a specialized Type 1 hypervisor based on illumos (OpenSolaris derivative), combining OS-level virtualization (Zones) with hardware virtualization (KVM) on a ZFS foundation.

sections.heading: Key Technologies
list: Zones - Lightweight OS-level virtualization containers
KVM - Full hardware virtualization for Linux, Windows, BSD
ZFS - Enterprise-grade file system with built-in data protection
DTrace - Dynamic tracing for deep system observability
Crossbow - Network virtualization stack

sections.heading: Key Features
list: Live from USB/PXE - Stateless hypervisor boots from image
imgadm - VM image management
vmadm - VM lifecycle management
ZFS Snapshots - Instant, space-efficient backups
Resource Controls - CPU caps, memory limits, I/O throttling

sections.heading: Use Cases
list: Cloud infrastructure (originally developed by Joyent)
High-performance containerized workloads
Multi-tenant hosting environments
Storage-intensive applications
Environments requiring advanced debugging (DTrace)
